title: Snail Species Could Predict Onset of Climate Change
text:
Snail Species Could Predict Onset of Climate Change Tue, 10/13/2015 - 2:00pm Get today's life science headlines and news - Sign up now! 
The humpback conch could become a valuable tool for saving the environment. 
A team composed of scientists from the University of Oslo in Norway and James Cook University in Australia are exploring how this species of mollusk reacts to environmental shifts from climate change, such as warmer temperatures and acidic seawater. 
Their work published in The Journal of Experimental Biology explains these snails have the ability to jump when they smell a nearby predator, which was used as a benchmark for this test. 
Climate change is expected to cause damage to coral reefs, but there’s no information on how snails and their relatives may react to this change, according to The New York Times. 
To test their hypothesis, humpback conchs were placed in a water tank filled with the odor from a cone snail in an effort to get the conch to jump. 
Oxygen consumption was tested to “see if increased warmth of acidity interfered with their physiology,” writes the Times. 
Alterations to the water did not impair the use of oxygen to enable the snail’s jumping ability. It only required a small amount of oxygen to get the conch to move.
